subsection.title: Domain and Range

li.p: What kinds of input does a function accept?
What are all the possible outputs a function will produce?

subsection.p: In math we have our own vocabulary we use to ask the same questions. The kinds of inputs a function will accept is called the domaindomain of the function. All the possible outcomes is called the rangerange.

introduction.p: Consider shopping online at a t-shirt company. Each t-shirt costs $13.00 and each time you click on the add to shopping cart your account adds a charge for $13.00.
Let C be the cost in dollars of purchasing N t-shirts. Therefore, C = f(N).
What kinds of input values for N does our function accept?
What kinds of output values does C create?

statement.p: T-shirt cost function. Enter the cost of buying N t-shirts.

li.p: Look at the inputs for N from the table.
Is it possible to buy 3.1415 t-shirts?
Is it possible to buy -7 t-shirts?
How would you classify all the possible input values? ? This is the domain of our function.
Now look at all the outputs C from the table.
Is it possible that the cost will be \$14 or \$15 or \$ 16?
How would you classify all the output values? This is the range of our function.
You can buy 0 t-shirts or 1 or 2 or more, but you can't buy 1.5 t-shirts or 2.63 t-shirts. You can only buy whole t-shirts, not fractions of shirts.
You can't choose to buy negative t-shirts so N can't be less than zero.

In math we say that the domain of our function is non-negative integers. This means the domain is the numbers N = 0, 1, 2, 3, etc. These are the only numbers that make sense for our function, the only numbers our function accepts.
If you don't add t-shirts to your online shopping cart, then N = 0, your cart will have no t-shirst and you won't pay anything, f(0) = 0.
If you choose N = 1 t-shirts you will pay $13.00
At N = 2 you pay $26.00
Notice you will never have a final checkout of $10.00 or $18.00. In fact, you will only pay in multiples of $13.00 because, again, you can't buy fractions of a t-shirt.
What are all the possible output values of our function?
You can't purchase a negative amount and you can't buy fractions of a t-shirt
Therefore the range of our function is all non-negative integer multiples of 13.

subsection.p: Sometimes a function can use any number as an input. Consider f(x) = x^2

statement.p: [@MODES(HTML=>'<iframe scrolling="no" src="https://www.geogebra.org/material/iframe/id/FRZgk5eU/width/413/height/350/border/888888" width="413px" height="350px" style="border:0px;"> </iframe>', TeX =>"A GeoGebra applet.");@]*
Drag the input value (point) on the horizontal axis left and right to see if the input shown has an output value.

li.p: Can you square \frac{-1}{2}?
Can you square 2.1?
Use a calculator to help you answer this next question.
Is there any number you can't multiply by itself?

statement.p: Therefore what is the domain of f(x)=x^2?
The domain is

subsection.p: Once we know the domain, we can then find all the possible results

set.member: \text{all real numbers greater than or equal to zero}

Drag the input value (point) on the horizontal axis left and right to see if the input shown has an output value.

li.p: Pick a negatvie number, square it. What is the sign of the result?
Pick a positive number, square it. What is the sign of the result?
Square the number zero. What is the result?
Will f(x) = x^2 ever generate a negative result (less than zero)?
Therefore what is the range of f(x)=x^2?
The range is

statement.p: Notice that the graph of f goes up forever, but it never drops below the horizontal axis.

subsection.p: Sometimes a function will only accept certain input values, or it may produce only certain kinds of results.
Consider f(x) = \sqrt{x}
This function will take real number inputs, as long as the input is not negative (you can't take the square root of a negative number).
On the other hand, the square root function only yields results that are positive or zero.
By graphing the function the domain and range become more apparent.
The figure shows the graph of f exists horizontally only from the origin and to the right. Therefore the domain of f is x \geq 0.
The figure also shows the graph of f exists vertically from the origin and up. Therefore the range of f is y \geq 0.
Note: since the vertical axis is called y, it means that y = f(x). Think of f(x) as the machine that takes x values and makes y values. Therefore we can use f(x) or y when referring to the range.

statement.p: [@MODES(HTML=>'<iframe scrolling="no" src="https://www.geogebra.org/material/iframe/id/KeUqTgkB/width/413/height/410/border/888888" width="413px" height="410px" style="border:0px;"> </iframe>', TeX =>"A GeoGebra applet.");@]*
The function f(x)= \sqrt{x} can be manipulated to change its domain and its range (wait til you get to reflections!)
By clicking on a checkbox you can see the domain (green dotted line) and the range (red solid line) of various forms of the function.

li.p: In what quadrant are both the domain and the range positive? Quadrant
In what quadrant are both the domain and the range negative? Quadrant
In what quadrant the domain positive and the range negative? Quadrant
In what quadrant the domain negative and the range positive? Quadrant
You can't take the square root of negative numbers
You can't allow the denominator of a fraction to be zero.

example.title: The algebraic method of finding the domain of any function with a square root
example.p: Set the expression under the root (the guts) greater than or equal to zero and solve. The result is the domain of the function.
Let f(x)=\sqrt{4x-9}. To find the domain set 4x-9 \geq 0 and solve.
So the domain of f is x \geq \frac{9}{4}

subsection.p: For functions written as fractions, we want to avoid 0 in the denominator. Set the denominator equal to zero and solve. Avoid these solutions since they are not part of the domain.
Let f(x)=\frac{\sqrt{x}}{9-x^2}
Set the denominator equal to zero then solve the equation.

p.em: In this example you need to know that not equal to is typed as != when you type your answer into an answer box

subsection.p: Can you solve the last equation? There are two solutions

statement.p: One solution comes from 3-x = 0. The solution is
The other solution comes from 3+x = 0. The solution is

subsection.p: We are not done yet. What about the numerator \sqrt{x} ? Are there any values that might cause trouble there?

statement.p: What are the only values of x the numberator will accept? (Use an inequality to state your answer)
Using the domains of the denominator you found, identify the domain of the entire function.
The denominator could not use the values x = \pm 3. So the domain of the denominator is x \neq -3 and x \neq 3.
The numerator can only use values x \geq 0.
Think about what values the numerator and the denominator have in common.
The domain of f is and

subsection.p: Try some algebraic methods of finding domain on your own. If you get stuck, use your calculator to make a graph of the function. Look to see where the graph exists.

li.p: Let f(x)= \sqrt{x-4}
What possible choices for x will allow the function to compute real valued outputs?
f has the domain
Let f(x) = \sqrt{4-x}
What possible choices for x will allow the function to compute real valued ouptuts?
f has the domain
Let f(x) = \frac{1}{x-7}
What possible choices for x will allow the function to compute real valued outputs?
f has the domain
Let f(x) = \frac{1}{x^2-9}
What possible choices for x will allow the function to computer real valued outputs?
f has the domain
In order for x-4 to be such that x - 4 \geqslant 0 (i.e. non-negative) then x \geqslant 4
In order for 4-x to be such that 4-x \geqslant 0 (i.e. non-negative) then x \leqslant 4
In order for x-7 to be such that x-7 \neq 0 (i.e. non-zero) then x\neq 7
In order for x^2-9 to be such that x^2-9 \neq 0 (i.e. non-zero) then x\neq \pm 3

subsection.p: Identifying the domain and range of a function just by looking at a formula can be difficult because you just have to know what to look for and that only comes with experience.

Often, a good way to determine the domain and range of a function is to graph it. Make a graph on a calculator or any graphing tool and try to identify where the function exists horizontally, this is the domain. Then try to identify where the funciton exists vertically, this is the range.
Always be careful not to think the domain or range must be continuous intervals. They may consist of different sections that together make up the entire domain or the entire range.

statement.p: [@MODES(HTML=>'<iframe scrolling="no" src="https://www.geogebra.org/material/iframe/id/AsPd6ZyS/width/413/height/370/border/888888" width="413px" height="370px" style="border:0px;"> </iframe>', TeX =>"A GeoGebra applet.");@]*
Use the point on the horizontal axis to drag the vertical line across the graph of the function f. The function exists when the vertical line intersects with the graph.
The domain is all the values for which the function exists.
Use inequalities to state the intervals that make up the domain of f
From left to right, the domain is and

[@MODES(HTML=>'<iframe scrolling="no" src="https://www.geogebra.org/material/iframe/id/sVku4sA4/width/413/height/370/border/888888" width="413px" height="370px" style="border:0px;"> </iframe>', TeX =>"A GeoGebra applet.");@]*
When you pick numbers from the domain, what are all the possible results?
Use the point on the vertical axis to drag the horizontal line across the graph. Use the line to identify all the possible outputs the function can yield. This is the range of the function.
From bottom to top, the range of the function is and

[@MODES(HTML=>'<iframe scrolling="no" src="https://www.geogebra.org/material/iframe/id/WhcSmWsn/width/413/height/370/border/888888" width="413px" height="370px" style="border:0px;"> </iframe>', TeX =>"A GeoGebra applet.");@]*
In green intervals along the horizontal axis denote the domain of the function.
The range of the function is shaded in range along the vertical axis.
Enter a 1 in the box if you got this problem correct

subsection.p: Also, the range is not necessarily between the endpoints of the graph.

statement.p: [@MODES(HTML=>'<iframe scrolling="no" src="https://www.geogebra.org/material/iframe/id/TdQ8ajW3/width/413/height/270/border/888888" width="413px" height="270px" style="border:0px;"> </iframe>', TeX =>"A GeoGebra applet.");@]*
Drag the left boundary point on the horizontal interval (in green) to change the domain of the function.
Set the domain to 0.4\leqslant x \lt 8
Under this domain, the range is

[@MODES(HTML=>'<iframe scrolling="no" src="https://www.geogebra.org/material/iframe/id/TdQ8ajW3/width/413/height/270/border/888888" width="413px" height="270px" style="border:0px;"> </iframe>', TeX =>"A GeoGebra applet.");@]*
Drag the left boundary point on the horizontal interval (shaded green) to change the domain of the function. The range is shaded on the vertical axis in red.
Set the domain to 2\leqslant x \lt 8
Under this domain, the range is

[@MODES(HTML=>'<iframe scrolling="no" src="https://www.geogebra.org/material/iframe/id/TdQ8ajW3/width/413/height/270/border/888888" width="413px" height="270px" style="border:0px;"> </iframe>', TeX =>"A GeoGebra applet.");@]*
Drag the left boundary point on the horizontal interval (in green) to change the domain of the function.
Set the domain to 5\leqslant x \lt 8
Under this domain, the range is
